headers.access-control-expose-headers: ETag, Link, Location, Retry-After, X-GitHub-OTP, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Used, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes, X-Poll-Interval, X-GitHub-Media-Type, Deprecation, Sunset
headers.vary: Accept, Authorization, Cookie, X-GitHub-OTP, Accept-Encoding, Accept, X-Requested-With
headers.x-github-media-type: github.squirrel-girl-preview; format=json, github.inertia-preview; format=json, github.starfox-preview; format=json, github.mockingbird-preview; param=sailor-v-preview; format=json
headers.x-oauth-scopes: admin:enterprise, admin:gpg_key, admin:org, admin:org_hook, admin:public_key, admin:repo_hook, gist, repo, user, workflow, write:discussion, write:packages

data.title: Azure Security Center Integration with Github
data.body:
## Summary
As customers start relying on cloud native technologies to bootstrap their application, they introduce dependencies within their app stack. Additionally, as code bases grow, it becomes difficult to ensure code cleanliness without using automated processes to periodically scan and alert for vulnerabilities. So it becomes imperative to get a holistic view of the security posture of applications. Customers also want to employ shift-left strategies and catch and remediate security threats as early in the software lifecycle as possible. 
This epic looks to bridge the gap between shift-left security practices and the ASC runtime.

**Problem Statement**
- An *azure IT admin* wants to understand what got deployed into his/her azure resource but **doesn't have the traceability into what repo/branch the code came from and which pipeline deployed artifacts to the resource**.
- An *azure IT admin* wants to get a complete picture of what security policies were evaluated for his/her azure resources as part of the CI/CD processes but **doesn't have visibility into which security scans were run on the left side and what were the results**.
- An *azure IT admin* wants to provide remediation steps for failed security policies in shift-left but **doesn't have visibility into what policies were violated on the left side**.
- An *azure IT admin* wants to enforce policies on the left side but **doesn't have the control knob to add policies on the left directly from the Azure portal**.

## Features
TBD

## EPD
Engineering: @ammohant 
Product: @azooinmyluggage, @anraghun 
Design: n/a

## Partner Teams:
Product: ASC team - Sunil Pai (sunil.pai@microsoft.com), Lavanya Kasarabada (lakasa@microsoft.com)

- [ ] Link with the features
